main_text:
Preference logic || Order typology
2.4 Order typology

One more property of preference relations needs to be specified. A
relation is antisymmetric if

\[
A\succcurlyeq B \wedge B\succcurlyeq A \rightarrow A=B
\text{ (antisymmetry of preference)}
\]


The categories summarized in the table below (based on Sen 1970a) are
standardly used to denominate preference relations that satisfy
certain logical properties.



Properties
Name(s) 

1.
reflexive, transitive
Preorder, Quasi-order 

2.
reflexive, transitive,
anti-symmetric
Partial order 

3.
irreflexive, transitive
Strict partial order 

4.
reflexive, transitive, complete
Total preorder, Complete quasi-ordering, Weak ordering 

5.
reflexive, transitive, complete,
anti-symmetric
Chain, Linear ordering, Complete
ordering 

6.
asymmetric, transitive, weakly
connected
Strict total order, Strong ordering
